title: R43689
content: The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2014 allocated $8.20 billion for the Environmental Protection Agency for FY2014, slightly more than the President's request. This was a decrease from the previous year's total appropriations for the EPA. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2014 allocated $8.20 billion for the Environmental Protection Agency for FY2014, including supplemental funds for water infrastructure and cleanup efforts in areas affected by Hurricane Sandy. The budget process for FY2014 considered discretionary appropriations under the Budget Control Act of 2011, with a statutory limit on spending through FY2021 and potential sequestration if deficit reduction measures were not enacted. The House and Senate passed budget resolutions with different spending levels and allocations for defense and nondefense. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2013 set total caps for FY2014 and FY2015 discretionary spending. No FY2014 appropriations bill for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies was introduced before October 1, 2013. On July 31, 2013, the markup was suspended. On August 1, 2013, the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee released a draft FY2014 Interior appropriations bill with a significant funding difference for EPA compared to the House draft. A temporary 16-day lapse in discretionary appropriations occurred between October 1, 2013, and October 16, 2013, leading to a partial government shutdown. The Continuing Appropriations Act was enacted on October 17, 2013. The Continuing Appropriations Act, 2014 ended the government shutdown on October 17, 2013, providing temporary appropriations at FY2013 levels until January 15, 2014. Further extensions maintained these levels until January 17, 2014, funding federal departments for the full fiscal year. This report compares FY2014 enacted appropriations for EPA accounts, programs, and activities to the President's FY2014 budget request and FY2013 enacted appropriations. The FY2014 budget request and FY2013 enacted appropriations included $577.3 million in supplemental funds for EPA accounts in the Disaster Relief Appropriations Act, 2013. The primary sources of information are the Joint Explanatory Statement and the House Committee on Appropriations report. The FY2013 enacted appropriations for EPA reflect sequestration under the Budget Control Act of 2011 and an additional across-the-board rescission. A breakout is provided for supplemental funding in P.L. 113-2. Historical comparisons of enacted appropriations by EPA accounts from FY2008 to FY2014 are presented in Table A-1, while Figure A-1 shows funding trends adjusted for inflation. For more details, refer to CRS Report R43207. The funding trends for the agency from FY1976 to FY2014 are depicted in Figure A-1, while Figure A-2 shows EPA's full-time-equivalent (FTE) employment ceiling from FY2001 to FY2014. The term appropriations in this report refers to total discretionary funds available to EPA for obligation, excluding permanent or mandatory appropriations. The majority of EPA's annual funding comes from discretionary appropriations, with a small portion from mandatory appropriations. From FY1996 to FY2013, EPA's appropriations were allocated across eight statutory accounts, with a ninth account added in FY2014 for the Hazardous Waste Electronic Manifest System Fund. This fund was established to track hazardous waste shipments and is supported by start-up appropriations and user fees. H.R. 3547 established a dedicated account to develop a cost-effective IT system for managing manifest transactions electronically under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act. EPA also administers a cleanup program providing financial assistance to state, local, and tribal entities for certain sites. The Brownfields program provides federal financial assistance to state, local, and tribal governmental entities for sites with known or suspected contamination that may hinder economic development. Responsible parties at these sites are not eligible for assistance, as they are accountable for cleanup costs. The program focuses on orphan sites where cleanup needs remain unaddressed, awarding competitive and formula-based grants. EPA is authorized to award competitive grants under Section 104(k) of CERCLA. The Brownfields program under CERCLA authorizes EPA to award grants for assessment and cleanup of contaminated sites, job training, and technical assistance. Funding for these grants comes from the STAG account, while program administration expenses are funded through the EPM account. In FY2014, $163.7 million was provided for the Brownfields program, exceeding the President's request and the previous year's appropriations. The funding level for FY2013 included disaster relief supplemental appropriations to address leaking underground storage tanks in areas affected by Hurricane Sandy. The LUST Trust Fund provides funding for EPA and states to enforce corrective actions for underground storage tank leaks. Congress established the fund to ensure cleanups are conducted by responsible parties or in emergencies. States have used the majority of their annual LUST Trust Fund for cleanups. The LUST Trust Fund, financed by a motor fuels tax, has seen a decline in balance due to funds being redirected for surface transportation projects. $2.4 billion was transferred to the federal Highway Trust Fund in FY2012, with an additional $1 billion authorized in 2014. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 expanded UST leak prevention provisions and authorized the transfer of $1 billion from the LUST Trust Fund to the Highway Trust Fund in 2014. This reduced the availability of funds for Subtitle I purposes, but the balance of the LUST Trust Fund has grown faster than the use of funds over time. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 expanded UST leak prevention provisions and authorized the transfer of funds from the LUST Trust Fund to support cleanup and underground storage tank leak prevention and detection regulations. Funding for these activities now comes from the trust fund, with a small portion from general revenues. The FY2014 enacted appropriations from the LUST Trust Fund to EPA support cleanup and UST leak prevention and detection activities. The EPM account in P.L. 113-2 provides funding for ecosystem restoration programs addressing water quality and pollution in specific areas of the US. Collaboration among EPA, federal agencies, state/local governments, and nonprofits is common. Funding for Great Lakes and Chesapeake Bay restoration is significant. President Bush established a Great Lakes Interagency Task Force in 2004 to guide federal efforts for protection and restoration. President Obama proposed the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative in FY2010, approved by Congress in P.L. 111-88. The initiative aims to improve coordination among federal programs to address ecosystem problems like invasive species and pollution through grants and agreements with various organizations. Funding consolidates existing Great Lakes programs. The Great Lakes Restoration Initiative was established in FY2010 with an initial appropriation of $475 million to EPA. Funding has been allocated to clean up contaminated sediments and coordinate federal programs for ecosystem issues. Congress has continued to provide funding, with $300 million allocated for FY2014. In FY2014, $70.0 million was appropriated for EPA's Chesapeake Bay program, which was $3.0 million less than the President's request and $15.7 million more than the FY2013 enacted appropriations. Despite past restoration efforts, the bay's overall health remains degraded by excessive nutrients and sediment. P.L. 113-76 allocated $16.9 million for "National Priorities" in the Science and Technology and Environmental Programs and Management accounts for FY2014. The funds were for high-priority water quality and availability research grants by not-for-profit organizations, with a 25% matching funds requirement. The remaining $12.7 million from the allocated $16.9 million in P.L. 113-76 for "National Priorities" in FY2014 was included in the EPM account. These funds were designated for competitive grants to not-for-profit organizations to provide technical assistance for improving water quality or safe drinking water, with a 10% matching funds requirement. $11.0 million was allocated for national level training and technical assistance, while $1.7 million was allocated for technical assistance to individual private well owners. These funds were not categorized as earmarks by Congress. The House and Senate have adhered to an earmark moratorium during the 112th and 113th Congress, precluding earmarks in annual appropriations bills for FY2011-2014. Definitions of earmarks were adopted in House and Senate rules, with separate definitions for transparency requirements. The EPA was established in 1970 in response to public concern about pollution. Congress has enacted numerous environmental laws and amendments over the years, providing funds for EPA to regulate air and water quality, manage hazardous waste, and clean up environmental contamination. EPA also awards grants to assist state and local governments in pollution control. The EPA awards grants to assist governments in controlling pollution to comply with federal environmental requirements and fund the implementation of laws. Congress has funded EPA programs through appropriations despite expired authorizations. House and Senate rules may allow funding for programs without authorization if no point of order is raised or rules are waived. Congress typically continues funding EPA programs through appropriations even after authorizations have expired. Table A-1 shows enacted appropriations for EPA from FY2008-FY2014, while Figure A-1 displays the agency's discretionary budget authority from FY1976 through FY2014. EPA's funding has increased over time to fulfill statutory responsibilities, reflecting the agency's evolving roles in addressing environmental issues. Despite representing a small portion of the federal budget, EPA's funding grew from $1.0 billion in FY1970 to a peak of $14.86 billion in FY2009. Adjusted for inflation, this peak includes regular appropriations of $7.64 billion in FY2009. EPA's funding peaked at $14.86 billion in FY2009, including regular appropriations of $7.64 billion and supplemental appropriations of $7.22 billion from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act. Adjusted for inflation, EPA's funding in FY1978 was slightly higher than in FY2009. EPA's authorized FTE employment ceiling increased by 18% from FY1990 to FY1999, with the largest increase occurring from FY1990 to FY1993. FTEs grew at a moderate rate of less than 1% per year, with a downward trend since FY2001. EPA's funding structure changed over the years, making historical comparisons difficult.
